concern:
title: I have a meeting with my thesis supervisor after not speaking to him for 9 months
I'm so nervous. I have a meeting with my thesis supervisor that I haven't spoken to for 9 months. I have to finish my thesis this school year because otherwise my courses that I passed will expire. My thesis has become such a mountain and it's been getting harder and harder to even find the motivation to climb the first two feet. 

Quick background: Started college in september 2012, finished my bachelors in july 2018 because of several back surgeries and depression. Then started my masters in september 2018 and passed all my courses in july 2019. Then I had to start writing my thesis and then had a nervous breakdown. Like full on depressed wanted to die that kind of thing. Covid started, which I (luckily) wasn't that affected by.  I got diagnosed with autism (which explained a. lot.) Got depressed again, started having back issues again. My parents finally convinced me to move back with them. 

It's been good. I have a job. My colleagues are really nice. My thesis supervisor is really nice. I have been very fortunate to have been born in a country in which college is relatively cheap and where mental care (and other healthcare is available and also relatively cheap). I have a loving family.

But that fucking thesis does my head in. I have anxiety attacks when I think about it. I stress about everyday but don't end up doing any work. I'm soooo close but I feel like a failure everytime I get feedback. And I lost all inspiration (if I had some in the first place.) 

I'm trying to pick myself up and get myself to work. But every tip and trick that is out there to get yourself started I just completely forget once the anxiety about the thesis lets itself know in my body. I just feel so horrible and want to do anything else not to feel all those knots in my stomach. I make up scenarios in my head where my thesis supervisor secretly hates me and thinks I'm a failure even though he's very kind. I think all my teachers think that I'm weak and weird and just find me a burden. I hate typing a paragraph and knowing it's going to be shit anyway. Graduatin college still feels so far out of my reach even though I have 14,000 word written that I hope aren't half bad.

I'm just at a loss and wanted to get this of my chest. I'm meeting with him in half an hour and my heart is beating like crazy.

Hey, thanks for chatting with me. I'm just feeling a bit overwhelmed with the amount of reading I have to do for my thesis. It feels like it takes me forever to get through each article.

concern:
title: Mastering out
Hi Everyone!

I currently attend an Ed.S dual degree program where I receive a M.Ed and Ed.S. I am 2.5/3 years in. As of December I have received an email from my program head stating that our cohort were “granted our M.Ed but won’t receive it in May” due to meeting the requirements of Ed.S then and receiving them both then. 

(Vent time; Question on the bottom)

The remaining of my time in the program and within the last year in clinical… has made me realize I’ve sacrificed so much of my mental health. I had an impromptu eval from my site supervisor Friday where she plainly asked me “Do you even want to be here?” Through this evaluation crushed me, it’s made me realize that I may not want to be here. As I’m sure as most academic personalities, I place such a high standard on myself that Ive realized placed in me in toxic academic environments and dealing with grad personnel within these environments. To the point where I’ve forgotten about my mental health by only thinking about the future, where I need to start thinking about the present me. Many in my life have been telling me to stick it out, but I’ve had this mindset for the last 2 years. I’m genuinely tired of sticking it out in a career where I’ve lost passion for. (Okay, vent time over)

Overall, I’m planning on mastering out. So my general question is, could I still plan to master out if my M.Ed is granted but it won’t be conferred until May of 2023? I’m afraid my program head will prevent me from receiving it.

concern:
title: Can Canadian Reserves summer training be balanced with grad school?
I am attending a Canadian grad school and am in my first year of my Biology PhD. The PhD research requires sample collection and environmental surveying, which must take place from the spring to the fall.

Because the program pays poorly and has extremely limited teaching assistant options, I am attempting to join my local regiment as an Army Reservist because it pays and could potentially get me a foot in the door for a government pension down the line. However, the recruiting website states that at least 2 summers of 2 months of full-time work are required in order to achieve status as a reservist. This seems very likely to conflict with my most important research work, and my supervisor may not permit it because the university has strict rules about how many hours/week a student may work outside their program.

Has anyone had any experience balancing the demands of working in the reserves with a graduate school program before? Is it reasonable to continue with my application to the Forces, or should I not bother?

concern:
title: Are you nervous or confident in lab?
Today my partner came to keep me company while I was working late in lab. I noticed how intrigued he was by everything in our lab (he is not in science or any science adjacent field). He was walking around touching all the instruments we had out, poking around (being mindful to not break or change anything) and was overall just very interested. 

It made me think: not even I go around poking around my lab because I'm worried I'll break something. Even when I come across an issue in lab (this is my first time doing labwork in years), I email my advisors for help instead of poking around old data to see if anything matches up because I don't want to accidentally delete something.

I guess it will take time to gain more confidence and I should probably up my anxiety meds but how are you usually in lab? Nervous or confidently inquisitive? I want to become like the latter but worried (ha) that I will never break out of my nervous shell.

concern:
title: Have you ever been so gaslit, disillusioned, or bullied that you took a break from, or quit your program? or the field entirely?
It’s happened to me and one other person I know in real life. Just curious if anyone else had a story to share similar to this.

The person I know was in residency after med school. Due to a terribly designed program and unnecessary overwork, a record number of 4 residents dropped out. It’s very rare for residents to leave a residency program. One left medicine altogether. My acquaintance took a year off, had a baby, then had to reapply for a new specialty.

Sometimes people in positions of authority suck; sometimes it’s just not a good fit; sometimes you’re in a program for the wrong reasons; sometimes you get triggered and have a nervous breakdown; sometimes you find out about some corruption or widely accepted nonsense in your industry that turns you off… 

And I’m sure a myriad other situations and outcomes.

I will be the first in my family to attend graduate school, if we can find a way to afford it. I have no idea when the finances are supposed to make sense. concern:
title: In my internship-based thesis, my thesis advisor wants me to include a SWOT analysis of my personal experience in my internship as an annex. My experience was not very positive and the internship supervisor is a member of my evaluation committee. How honest should I be, or should I not do it at all?
I didn't have the best experience in my internship due in large part to poor management by my internship supervisor, who will be reading my thesis and will be a member of my defense jury. I also think I could have found solutions to the problems if I had been more assertive and decisive, but I was so lost and confused for the first half of my internship that I didn't see the solutions until it was too late. I'm afraid that including all of this will paint both myself and my supervisor in a bad light, but I don't know what other Weaknesses and Threats to include in my SWOT analysis that don't risk doing either of these things. Should I be honest, or should I be more vague and downplay these elements (which I think risks coming across as evasive BS), or should I just ask my professor if I can send him the SWOT separately rather than as part of the thesis?

title: Value of a Bachelors Degree in SCS

Currently looking at transferring to the Georgetown School of Continued Studies (SCS) for my bachelors degree.

I currently work full-time in finance (i have a graduation return offer) and as such, have struggled significantly with my current situation (attending class in person, being a full time student). My grades have struggled as the result of (trying) to balance full time employment with full time academics. It is for this reason I am considering the GU SCS (which offers classes fully online).

Problem is, I intend on attending law or grad school down the line. I want to see if attending such a program will hinder my chances. concern:
title: Tips and Tricks to Avoid Procrastinating
Last semester entering my second year, I started off good and while dealing with depression, anxiety, and addictions, the semester kinda spiraled. I realized I got to a point where the day OF one of my classes final papers was due I stated the assignment (the liar in my head that says “ah I work well under pressure or ah I can do it last minute and still get a good grade”) not anymore. I waited and waited for who knows what to start that assignment and I had the worst time of my life. I’m traumatized. I was so stressed out finals week that I threw up from nausea, had major major anxiety, pretty much broke down half way and started ending my sentences midway because I just could not keep going for the life of me. That level of stress was traumatic and I know it’s my fault. I need to make changes. I promised myself if I did that to myself again I would drop out. And since I have Qualifying exams this semester, I’m like SpongeBobs brain, all chaos. All I can think about are my professors thinking “how did she get in with this work? Or just thinking the worst of my capabilities. Which I also feel like I’ve partly lost. My writing was so good before, now it’s hard to make a sentence sound good enough. I bombed those finals so hard, when I think about it I get anxiety again. I feel kinda numb too, I’m worried that I didn’t really panic knowing those papers were due that day. Not panicking means I’m not caring anymore and that’s scaring me. Factors like being far away from home and being lonely in a new city with no real friends, mental health struggles, and life in general has been bumpy for all of us the last two years. Have any of you experienced this stress trauma before? How have you dealt with it? Or if you have any tips on being productive and avoid procrastinating please let me know. I’m desperate. I don’t want to end up hating my career bc of grad school. I LOVE what I do, I love being an archaeologist, I can’t see myself doing anything other than that. Which is why dropping out of grad school is NOT a choice. I have to finish, but I need help managing it all along the way. Thanks in advance.

concern:
title: How to deal with a toxic labmate
Hello everyone, I previously posted about this person. Let’s call her Jenny for the sake of this post. 
Jenny has been making my life a living hell. 
Every movement I make, every letter i type on the keyboard what I eat, where I eat, it all causes Jenny to make a mockery out of me.

Now, Jenny has been snitching on us so the dr responsible for our lab appointed her as our boss. She makes us go carry heavy stuff/ manual labor or go buy stuff she needs for her experiments and if we say NO she used the “I’m a boss here, if you don’t follow me i’ll tell the drs and you can be kicked out of the program” card. 
I have been her target for 2 years now and she is a semester behind in the program.
Today we had a small celebration for one of our colleagues for successfully beating cancer. Let’s call that colleague Lily.
Now Jenny got a cake without telling anyone that it was today, and when we wanted to pay our parts back she (Jenny) said : “ I only take payments in USD , Go to the exchanger and unless you bring me USD i am not accepting your payment. “ mind you that both pounds and USD are used here and our country’s pounds is more readily available for small payments. For example it is extremely difficult to find a 5$ bill but very easy to find it in pounds.
It is the way she gives orders and when i confront her she twists the scenario making it seem i am the one causing trouble and i am sick of it. 
In front of us “ i am the best here you need to follow me” but if the drs give her a compliment she directly switches to “ on no , i’m feeling very humble! You’re giving me too much credit, I think the harmony in our lab is a team effort~”
The minute the drs walk out she’s like” are they stupid!”
Even a few days ago, Lily received a call from someone who was getting treatment with her but wasn’t unfortunate enough to recover and that she wanted to talk to LiLy and bid her farewells and Jenny told Lily to block her ….
Another instance was she told me i wasn’t raised right because i said goodbye to my advisor not the other way around. 
She also keeps criticizing that she is fed up with the speed of my typing, and no my paper has a deadline i am not stopping for her.
3 years ago during masters Jenny was my roommate and her space was a mess .
She made up a no eating rule in the room yet she eats there herself and when i confronted her she said “ your food smells of spices mine doesn’t so i am allowed to eat here but you’re not”
She also told Lily that i was messy which LiLy replied to “ how could you live together with someone this messy, you poor thing must’ve been so stressed”
While i swear to anything you believe in , that i used to tidy her spot if i just wanted to walk decently in the room.
She also made a “you’re not allowed to turn the AC rule” but when she was hot she turned it and said but i am hot, and when i told her when I was feeling hot you didn’t let me turn it on and she replied “but i wasn’t hot”
The other day she asked me why do you out spaces after semi columns. And at a conference abroad last year she said she didn’t need a sim . Bought one and put it in my phone, and out of nowhere she says “give me the sim i need to talk to my boyfriend”
I said no. She stood on the sidewalk and yelled you piece of shit you’re not giving me the sim!!! You’ll see , i’ll harm you, you’ll see! Like she waited for the sim to be handed to her.
And the last day we were supposed to split an uber to the airport and then last minute she said there is no place for me . When i told her that is not what she said she lied to my face and said she has no idea what I am talking about and she convinced other that i must be dumb.Luckily there was another student who witnessed the entire thing and told her , i have heard it too.also she fatshames people after she lost weight.

It is like every movement of mine is either rejected ,refuted or twisted to appear as if i am in the wrong. She is multiple faced and tbh doesn’t deserve the power she is been given .

title: Starting my non-thesis paper
So it’s my last semester of my Master’s (History), assuming I graduate in May. I know I need to do more on my paper (AKA actually write it so I can finish it). I started in November, but only because I had a meeting with one of my advisors and needed to show where I was with my argument. I had about 15 or so pages done, mostly introduction but a brief overview of my main tenets. 

I sent this draft to this same advisor and he has NEVER gotten back to me with feedback despite in-person requests. He also never returned my seminar research paper with any feedback, (completed in December), despite multiple in-person requests. Nor did the historiography seminar paper I completed for another class (different professor) get returned with any feedback, despite an email request. 
My other advisor, whom I work for as a research assistant, briefly talks to me about ideas but our conversations skew back towards their work 75% of the time. 

I’ve been reading endlessly, it seems, and have a clearer idea of where I want to take my argument. But I’m finding it hard to start writing again without receiving feedback for my last seminar papers, which contained the foundation l of my argument, my thoughts on the trajectory of the field, and what I feel like my contribution adds to my field.

Looking for advice and encouragement on how to proceed when I feel like what I’m saying (and requesting in follow-up!) is clearly not worth anyone’s time.

concern:
title: my advisor was upset that i couldn't remember the name of the professor who is teaching one of my classes this semester
My advisor kinda hates me. He didn't like how my first year of PhD went; I had to spend a lot of time adjusting to the rigor of my program for which I honestly was not prepared. I also developed epilepsy and took awhile to find the right meds to quell the episodes, etc. In the midst, I got myself on probation due to a C. This prohibited me from sitting in for qualifier. Anyways, I have started to blossom particularly over the summer and now as a second year. Lexapro, lamictal, and my tenacity have been integral.

My professor was even really happy and surprised by how well one of my presentations to our industrial partner went. ANYWAYS, I was doing a routine meeting with him today (we meet maybe thrice a year) and he asked how my classes were going. I told that I honestly was feeling way more adjusted and having a lot of fun. I love my polymers class a lot and the professor there is a close acquaintance of mine.

But my other course, the professor is new and I simply never memorized his name. He is Chinese and his name is honestly hard for me to pronounce. I appreciate his class and ask questions actively because the material is one I engage in. I have no disrespect for him at all!

My advisor asked me about who was teaching the class this semester. I believe that I knew his name, but I was certain that I would mispronounce it. And I did not want to do this as it is disrespectful. Additionally, I have a lot of anxiety going into these meetings given my advisor's pre-eexisting disdain for me.  I just knew that what would come out of my mouth would be stutter or embarrassment. So I just blurted out, hmm I honestly don't remember. Lol. concern:
title: Should I feel bad about moving back?
I’m an international student, and I got into a great R1 university for a Masters. Moved here last fall, and I graduate this spring. I have the option of applying for a PhD after I graduate while I’m on OPT here which was originally the plan. But I’ve thought about it a lot, and I think it might be better for me to move back to my home country and work in my area of interest for a bit before applying for a PhD. I already did one cycle of PhD applications before this Masters and didn’t get in anywhere for the PhD, and got the Masters instead. 

Since the PhD was the original plan, I really moved here thinking I won’t move back for a while. But now that I’m thinking about moving back, I’m a bit bothered by it. I love it here, I’ve made amazing friends that I go out with regularly, but I also don’t want to apply for a PhD when I’m not sure about it. I love my home country, so it’s not like I’ll hate moving back. But it’s like being stuck between a rock and a hard place.

Is moving back home and trying again after a while okay? I keep spiralling and thinking it’s some type of failure on my part for not having figured it out. Am I screwing up my chances by moving back? Or will I screw them up worse by applying when I’m not sure? 

Funnily enough, I’ve been so focused on studying that I haven’t even enjoyed my move here, nor have I explored anything in the city or the country much. So all of it just seems like a bunch of missed opportunities, and i feel like I’ll be going back with almost no new experiences. 

I don’t know what answer I expect. But I’m mentally messed up at this point and I feel like I don’t have any options in front of me, and nothing seems worth it anymore. 


PS. Scheduled a meeting with a therapist asap. Gotta love student wellness centres.

concern:
title: Anxiety about deadlines
I work 30 hours a week over 4 days and 1 day a week I go to uni to study my Master’s. It’s a 2 year course and I’m in the 2nd year.

My deadlines are causing me anxiety, especially dissertation which is due on 29th September. The grade I get for dissertation will be counted as a double module, so there’s a lot of pressure. I get anxiety at night thinking about work and uni deadlines, and all the stuff I have to do the next day. 

My uni have made this document with the ideal dissertation timeline, and it says we should get our literature review done by the end of February. It’s now the 25th and I’ve only done 900 words and I’m starting to panic.  I was even thinking about taking unpaid leave from work to try and finish my lit review. Annoyingly I have no leave left because I’ve had to use it for a uni field trip.

I’m on track to finish the course- in the 8 assignments I’ve done I’ve got 2 distinctions (highest grade) 6 merits (middle grade) and 1 pass (lowest grade) But I’m not amazingly good at academic writing. In my undergraduate dissertation I didn’t do that well. I got 55% so a 2:2 grade, luckily somehow I still got a 2:1 overall for my degree. The pass mark for Master’s courses in England where I live is 50%. So I’m worried that I might not pass. Also I want to do primary research for my dissertation which is going to be very time consuming. Admittedly my undergrad dissertation was very rushed. I did the whole thing in 2 months including primary research. 

Does anyone have any tips for how to keep anxiety at bay? Yoga and meditation help me, but I have to be soo consistent with them. This morning I didn’t meditate and I think that might be why I feel anxious now.

concern:
title: Can a PI extort you?
I've posted here about this PI before, so look there for context. Short version: because other people in my lab have done virtually nothing to help me with this labor intensive developmental project, I had to shell out an extra 1k to register for this semester to finish my thesis. 

Today, I met with my PI to discuss the thesis, which I thought was coming to a close. Toward the end of the meeting, he asked me to start collecting data again so that we can publish. I told him that I'm not interested in doing that, because I want to concentrated on defending my thesis and getting my degree. He said something like, "Well, the babies will age out if you wait any longer. It shouldn't take you that long to add the data." This pissed me off because he has no clue how long it takes to find parents, schedule appointments, run the study, code the data, compile the data, clean the data, and analyze it. I told him that I was hesitant to collect again after last summer when I spent my own time and money driving back and forth 6 hours to collect 85% of my sample in my hometown with no help from the lab. He said "This isn't just a homework assignment. This is a job. If I don't get a publication out of this, I'm not interested in the project at all." I asked, "Do you mean you wouldn't sign off on my thesis?" and he said yes. Has anybody else dealt with something like this? Like, is this legal???

Edit: For more clarification, I’m a master’s student who was supposed to defend in December 2022. I’m enrolling in a PhD program in the fall, so the legality thing is an exaggeration, but the PI being as asshole about this isn’t.

concern:
title: How to handle hostile listeners when presenting?
I am a 1st year grad student and am currently preparing to present my research to the rest of my research group for the first time. While I am confident in my ability to field genuine questions about my work, I am anxious about dealing with one senior group member in particular.

Having been in this lab since undergrad, I routinely see him ask questions to presenters in group meeting that are intended to sow discomfort or undermine their confidence. It comes across as juvenile, in the sense that I don't believe he is asking out of legitimate curiosity but rather as a way to assert dominance among his peers. They tend to be tedious, hardly important questions, often requiring back-tracking after the presenter has moved on.

How have you dealt with people like this in your time in grad school? I don't want him to walk all over me, else he'll interpret me as an easy target and bother me more in the future. At the same time, I don't want to harm my reputation with an unprofessional response.

concern:
title: Work life balance during a PhD in organic chemistry?
Hello all,

I have been lucky to spend this past year of mine doing a post-baccalaureate at a well known university, but even more importantly, with amazingly supportive and flexible advisors. The lab I work in doesn't have any strict hours, and half the people don't even show up on the weekend (and those that do, don't do it every single weekend). Having seen the labs at my undergrad (and the 70+ hrs/week students put in there), I know this idea of a *genuine* work life balance is often times thought of as a myth, however, now that I've been exposed to how wonderful things *could* be, I'm having trouble wrapping my head around the fact that most labs in most schools simply don't operate that way.

I want to get my PhD in organic, and currently I have an offer from a good school that I'm considering (Boston College), however, it seems that most labs/PIs there (and elsewhere) are fairly strict about the minimum 6 days a week BS, and some even enforce minimum hours/day. 

I personally think that if you're good about time management and planning things out then coming in on the weekend should be more of a rarity, but most profs don't feel that way.

I guess I'm wondering if anyone else has been able to achieve a genuine/healthy work life balance doing their PhD in chemistry, and if so, how did you approach this with your advisor? Were they aware that you weren't in 24/7? Did you say something to them to establish this boundary? I'm not sure what I should be looking for/if it's a possibility that I could find something similar to the lab I'm currently at.

Unfortunately I cannot stay in this lab/school, so I have to consider other options.

Thanks in advance!

concern:
title: Bumbling through the admissions cycle
So this is my second admissions cycle applying to MA and Ph.D. programs. I was accepted to a couple of programs last year but didn't receive enough funding, so did not enroll. I've mostly decided that I won't go through another cycle if I don't get enough funding this year because the rest of my life has been in limbo while trying to determine if I'm moving/departing from my LTR/etc. I could change my mind after a week of good rest but who knows when that will be.

Part of me also feels so tired from the whole process. I work full time and was taking classes part-time for a number of years and then doing all of this freelance work to build my CV *and then* working on my application materials. I've been extremely lucky in that I did very well in my classes and also had a ton of opportunities come my way. I love learning and researching so much, and wish to be doing it full-time instead of splitting my efforts. I've already been through a 1-year grad program, and know how intense that year was. The work itself doesn't phase me since I'm used to working 50 - 60 hours a week between my job and whatever else I get myself into. Okay, I'm a bit of a workaholic. And I am legitimately tired. 

I also feel like I am stumbling through the admissions process even though I had some guidance (non-profit program for underserved students). The admissions process is not intuitive and sometimes I feel like a deer in headlights, and I spend days cringing over a wrong step. Anyone else?

concern:
title: Life stressors, grades and finishing- Long post.
I just feel the need to share this as it feels cathartic to release this into the internet void. I have had the absolute worst life circumstances thrown my way while trying to complete and pass my classes for my degree. I started school in Fall 2021 with an accelerated program to finish in a year. Previously to starting school, my parents, who were married for 33 years, abruptly and sadly ended their marriage. My dad, who was in my life sort of consistently, completely abandoned, and left our family never to talk to us again. He married another woman who was horrific and edged us out of his life. My mom, who was extremely dependent on my dad, lost everything including her money. She was always sort of absent but it became much worse and devastating to witness and put a lot of pressure on me to help her out. Especially when COVID hit, that added a lot more pressure in general. I don't say this lightly but it absolutely devastated me. I had terrible depression, OCD and awful anxiety, but nonetheless I started my program hoping to push that aside. Another thing to note, is that I came from a very religious background and through connecting the dots realized that it was actually a cult that my dad started and funded mid way through the semester. I realized how much control and manipulation both my parents had put me through my whole life. It was overwhelming to say the least. My brain sort of broke around mid terms and I was crying through every single test. I, of course failed those exams, because I was so devastated and hurt, shocked and in deep grief. I was taking shots of tequila in the AM to calm myself down before my classes and mid terms to try to work through the pain, but it was to no avail. To avoid failing my classes, I took a leave of absence and didn't take my finals. At the same time, I was let go of my part time job which was helping support me with living expenses during my time in school. Lastly, my marriage was really strained and felt like it was also falling apart. The amount of stress and grief was overwhelming, and I was in a such a low place that I checked myself into an IOP (intensive out patient) therapy center. So for the first part of 2022, I went to over 400 hours of therapy to heal myself and deal with the intense trauma of it all. I lived off of credit cards and money I had saved for myself to pay for my program. As the year progressed, I was able to come above water for the first time and start getting back into my program. I had to take every final and write all of my research papers almost a year later, while also completing the current fall semester. It was so difficult to recall the information, but I was able to scrape by and finish with not stellar grades but still passed. I also enrolled back into the fall semester of 2022 and am finishing up my program (hopefully) this spring. Unfortunately my grades were sub par my first semester that I may be below the graduation requirement (3.0) , but I am hoping that my program will allow me to still walk and just pass me so I can move on from this life. I had to take out loans to live while I am in school because it is so involved, I cut ties with my parents (I was really close with my mom so that hurt), and am grinding out this semester to finally fucking finish! This isn't a post about pushing through adversity or anything, it is just venting that, this whole experience has been so hard and I am ready to be done. Lastly, being in your 30's in school is EXTREMELY harder than when I was in my young 20's.

I thought huh, maybe I should reach out to a crisis line.

People keep telling me I need to be patient, and I should be happy. But Im just exhausted and easily upset. So, is anyone else lonely? Burned out? What do you do?

concern:
title: Feeling painfully unprepared for my quals this semester
I'll keep the background short, but grad school has been a RIDE for me. Mental health? Questionable. Physical health? Dubious. New PI straight out of a post doc? On maternity leave for my first semester so my labmate and I were left to set up a brand new lab if that gives you any perspective- I don't have any work from past grad students that I can show as preliminary data, there were no experiments running when I came in, and my project is still not clearly defined. That last one is, admittedly, entirely my fault. I very much want to work on something that is within the scope of the lab, but that my PI has not worked on before personally.

Here's the issue: she wants me to do my qualifying exam in January, but I still feel like I know nothing about the state of our field. It's small, and I think I know what's been looked at by the biggest group in the area, but I don't know if what I'm doing is too close to their work. I feel very overwhelmed when trying to write up my specific aims, because I don't know how big or small my scope should be considering that I have no data and will have to do 100% of the work myself. I've been trying to look for some resources on how to determine scope and things like that, but I've been reading for a good chunk of break and I actually feel more uncertain than when I started.

If anyone has thoughts on starting from the ground up like this, I would very much appreciate it. All my friends are in established labs with multiple undergrads, lab managers, post docs, and years of work to lean on but I feel like I'm in way over my head here.

concern:
title: Panicking about not finding a permanent lab after rotations
I'm freaking out. This is my first year of grad school and in my program (bio) you rotate through up to 3 labs before choosing where to stay permanently. I started my #2 rotation recently and thought all was good. However, the PI told me on day 1 of the rotation that the funding situation had changed for the worse and he couldn't commit to keeping me on longterm. I couldn't believe it because I had asked about this before rotating. No matter though, I can go back to lab #1 though right? NOPE, turns out that PI said almost word for word the same thing.

I don't think this is about my performance since the #2 PI told me before I had even had a chance to do any work. Also, we have a group Whatsapp chat for our cohort and a lot of people are hearing similar things. One person's rotation PI said it is because there was a protest and stipends went up by a lot so PIs are now saying they can't afford to take new people on.

I can't stop picturing the worst outcomes. What if I can't find a lab, do I have to drop out of the program? I gave up so much to come here, broke my lease, quit my job, even ended a relationship. What do I do?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! How are you feeling today? Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about?
Hey. I'm feeling a bit overwhelmed actually. I've been really thinking about changing careers because my current job just isn't doing it for me, and I'm not sure where to start.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared her concerns about career dissatisfaction and desire for change, detailing her thoughts and feelings about her current job and aspirations. She has provided context, including her interest in research and academia, and her financial concerns. There is a clear understanding of her needs and goals. It seems appropriate to transition to the Guiding phase to explore motivation and potential options for change.

dialogue_total.statement: That sounds like a big decision weighing on your mind. What is it about your current job that makes you feel it's not right for you anymore?
It's mostly that the work feels really unfulfilling. I deal with tech stuff all day, and I just don't see the impact or meaning in what I'm doing. Plus, the environment isn't the greatest.

statement.reasoning: The client has demonstrated a clear recognition of the discrepancy between their current situation and desired values, identified potential change paths, and diminished sustain talk regarding their current job. However, specific goals and confidence levels remain unclear, suggesting a need for further exploration in the Guiding phase to clarify steps and build confidence.

dialogue_total.statement: Finding fulfillment and meaning in your work seems really important to you. What sort of impact or meaning would you like to see in your career that you feel is currently missing?

I want to feel like I'm contributing to something bigger, maybe through research or public service, where I can explore topics that really interest me like sociology or theology. I just want to feel passionate and genuinely invested in what I do.

statement.reasoning: The client acknowledges the discrepancy between their current job and desired values, showing clear Change Talk. They have expressed a specific change goal of exploring more fulfilling career paths. Confidence seems implicitly high given the willingness to pursue further education despite financial concerns. Ambivalence about change is low, indicating readiness to plan specific steps.

dialogue_total.statement: Exploring a new career path that aligns with your passions and interests sounds like it could be really rewarding. Given your interest in research and public service, perhaps creating a goal to explore opportunities or educational programs in these areas might be a good start. Would you like to brainstorm some actions you could take, like researching specific fields or networking with professionals in those areas?

Yeah, I think that could be really helpful. I feel like I need to get a better sense of what options are out there and maybe talk to people who are actually doing those jobs. I'm just not sure where to begin with that.

statement.reasoning: The client has a clear goal of changing to a more fulfilling career and is interested in researching and networking with professionals. Barriers such as educational costs and uncertainty about options have been identified. The client acknowledges needing to talk to people in desired fields. The client demonstrates openness to further education and career exploration, showing readiness through action reflections and confidence. The goals of Choosing are met, so moving forward is appropriate.

dialogue_total.statement:
therapist: Navigating these changes can feel daunting, but it's great that you're open to exploring new possibilities. Starting with small, manageable steps can make a big difference. Diving into research can help, such as looking into educational programs or online courses in sociology or theology. Additionally, connecting with professionals currently working in research or public service can offer valuable insights. I'd encourage setting a goal to reach out to a few people in these fields, perhaps through professional networking sites or community events. 

It's wonderful that you're motivated to take these steps, and remember, it's okay to take things one step at a time. Moving forward, perhaps setting a timeline for some of these actions could keep you on track and boost your confidence. Keep in mind, you have the strength and resilience to navigate this journey, and I'm here to support you along the way. If you feel ready, we could touch base in our next session to see how things are progressing and discuss any new insights or questions that come up.
Thanks, that sounds like a good plan. I appreciate your support; I'll start looking into those options and see what I can find.

statement.reasoning: The session has effectively covered a summary of goals, steps to explore new career paths, and coping strategies. A next-step plan is in place, and the client expressed readiness to proceed with it.

concern:
title: Those who went back to school for a more rewarding career change, was it worth it? Any advice on my situation is appreciated
I'm a 23y/o woman seeking a career change. I graduated in 2021 with a BA in Communication Science and Rhetorical Studies, along with a certificate in Digital Studies and History.

Currently, I work as a technical writer for a Silicon Valley tech startup. While the pay is good, the work environment is far from fulfilling. I work with software and Al, and truthfully it's quite soul crushing. I don't measure success solely by income, although still important, I'm really eager to pursue something that aligns more with my interests and makes some kind of meaningful impact.

My primary interest lies in research and academia, particularly in sociology or religious theology. I've always been fascinated by the history of religion's influence on global affairs, social development, government regulation, etc. I spend most of my free time reading on these topics. However, I'm aware of the challenges in these fields: they're highly competitive, underfunded, and aren't expected to grow. (Rip humanities)

Beyond academia, I'm open to exploring other fulfilling paths such as public policy, government, or the medical field. However, I'm uncertain where to begin in discovering options in these fields that I could pursue.
I'm willing to pursue further education through a master's or doctorate to make this career switch, but I want to be sure it's not a dead end. Currently, I'm still paying off my undergraduate loans ($25,000 remaining).

I suppose I'm really looking for advice from those who have been in a similar situation. With my current background, where can I go from here without net to start from scratch? I really need to get out of Silicur Valley world and the people in it. Apologies for the long post, and thanks in advance to all.
